Introduction

Breastfeeding is the optimal method for feeding infants due to its numerous health benefits for both the infant and the mother.  Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended for the first 6 months of life, with continued breastfeeding while introducing solid foods during the first year.

This article will review various features of breastfeeding, including its physiology, effects on infant nutrition and immunity, benefits to maternal health, common concerns, and contraindications.

Lactogenesis

Lactogenesis is the process of milk production and secretion, including the changes in the mammary glands necessary to transition from undifferentiated glands to full lactation following birth.  Lactogenesis is divided into the following stages:

  • Stage I (secretory initiation) occurs during midpregnancy (~16 weeks gestation); pregnancy hormones (eg, prolactin, progesterone, human placental lactogen) promote mammary gland development and lactocyte differentiation (cells responsible for milk synthesis).  Rising prolactin stimulates lactoctyes to produce the first product of lactation (colostrum), which is a thick, yellowish fluid that contains high concentrations of immunoglobulin and the protein lactoferrin.  Colostrum provides essential immune protection and helps to establish the infant's digestive system; although it can be expressed prenatally, it is most often expressed postnatally (prior to stage II of lactogenesis).  Further milk development and production is inhibited by high levels of placental progesterone.
  • Stage II (secretory activation) is characterized by the onset of larger volumes of milk secretion.  This generally occurs at postpartum days 2-4, when the inhibitory signal is removed with the sharp decline in progesterone levels (due to removal of the placenta).  This process also requires high levels of prolactin, insulin, and cortisol.
  • Stage III (lactation) is marked by the ongoing production of mature milk, which is developed around postpartum day 10.  Mature milk is secreted as milk is removed from the mammary glands.  Prolactin is required to sustain production, and oxytocin is required for milk ejection (
    figure 1
    ).  Suckling activates afferent neural signals to the hypothalamus to release oxytocin, which stimulates myoepithelial cell contraction within the alveolar clusters for milk letdown.

The high prolactin levels (

figure 2
) required to sustain lactation disrupt the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis (
figure 3
) by inhibiting GnRH release, which prevents anterior pituitary gland gonadotropin release (ie, FSH, LH).  Without FSH, a dominant follicle does not form and ovarian estrogen is not produced, leading to lactational amenorrhea.  The hypoestrogenic state of breastfeeding commonly leads to low estrogen symptoms, including vasomotor symptoms (eg, hot flashes, night sweats), vaginal dryness, and decreased bone density (reversible following weaning).

  • Stage IV begins when involution occurs, with cessation of milk secretion/removal and apoptosis of the mammary gland (remodeling of breast tissue back to the nonpregnant state).

Infant benefits

Breast milk composition

Breast milk contains the ideal balance of nutrients, including carbohydrates (lactose), proteins (casein, lactoferrin), fats (mainly in the form of triglycerides), vitamins, and minerals.  It is dynamic and evolves to meet the nutritional needs of the growing infant.  In addition, breast milk contains immunoglobulins (IgA), lysozymes, white blood cells, proteases, hormones, growth factors, and gastrointestinal mediators.  Therefore, consuming breast milk has the following benefits:

Short-term benefits

  • Gastrointestinal function:  The active substances of breast milk stimulate growth and development of the gastrointestinal tract, increasing the rate of gastric emptying and intestinal lactase activity while decreasing intestinal permeability.  In preterm infants, breast milk significantly decreases the risk for necrotizing enterocolitis.
  • Immunity:  The high concentration of IgA forms a protective layer on mucous membranes, which leads to a decreased risk for gastroenteritis/diarrhea, respiratory infections, otitis media, urinary tract infections, and neonatal sepsis.
  • Decreased rates of sudden infant death syndrome.

Long-term benefits

  • Decreased risk for chronic conditions, including type I diabetes mellitus and inflammatory bowel disease
  • Improved dental health
  • Decreased risk for obesity, type II diabetes mellitus, and certain cancers (eg, leukemia) later in life

Maternal benefits

Breastfeeding is associated with both short-term and long-term benefits to the mother:

Short-term benefits

  • Reduced risk for postpartum hemorrhage:  The release of oxytocin required for milk letdown also acts on the uterus to facilitate uterine contractions, which decreases postpartum blood loss and increases the rate of uterine involution.
  • Delayed ovulation:  The high prolactin levels that sustain milk production inhibit GnRH release (
    figure 2
    ), which prevents the release of gonadotropins and ovulation (ie, lactational amenorrhea).  This is important because short interpregnancy intervals are associated with poor maternal and neonatal outcomes.
  • Weight loss:  Breastfeeding may facilitate quicker return to prepregnancy weight.

Long-term benefits

Breastfeeding is associated with decreased rates of breast and ovarian cancer, hypertension, and type II diabetes mellitus.

Contraception

The postpartum period is an ideal and important time to initiate contraception.  Considerations for contraceptive methods must include breastfeeding desires and goals to prevent early discontinuation of both contraceptive methods and breastfeeding.

Estrogen and progesterone directly inhibit prolactin's effects on the mammary alveolar cells during pregnancy; therefore, there is concern that early initiation of hormonal contraceptives may impair milk quality and quantity.  There is little impact on lactation with progestin-only contraceptives (eg, progestin-containing IUD, progesterone implant, progestin-only pills), therefore, they can be initiated immediately following delivery.  Combined estrogen/progestin oral contraceptive pills should not be initiated until 6 weeks postpartum when lactation is fully established.

Complications

  • Nipple pain:  The initiation of breastfeeding is associated with a normal sensitivity of the nipple.  This is distinguished from injury that may manifest as bruising, cracking, and/or blistering.  This is most often due to a poor latch technique and/or infant ankyloglossia (ie, tongue tie).  Management is with education on proper breastfeeding latch (
    figure 5
    ) and evaluation of infant tongue mobility.
  • Engorgement:  This is distinguished between primary and secondary engorgement.
    • Primary engorgement occurs early postpartum in conjunction with lactogenesis stage II (ie, when milk production increases) and is due to interstitial edema of the breast.  Treatment is conservative with analgesics, hot and cold compresses, and hand expression; this condition is self-limited and often resolves within 3-5 days.
    • Secondary engorgement occurs later and is associated with inadequate milk removal.  Treatment with timed milk removal (eg, feeding, pumping) is important because this can lead to clogged ducts or mastitis.
  • Localized duct narrowing (ie, clogged milk duct):  This complication can result from uneven milk removal caused by electric breast pumps, nipple shields, or improper infant latch with inefficient milk emptying.  It presents as a painful, palpable lump or mass within the breast without systemic symptoms (eg, fever, chills).  Treatment involves hot compresses, frequent feeds (while minimizing use of an electric breast pump), and gentle manual massage.  Inadequate resolution often leads to mastitis.
  • Galactocele (ie, milk retention cyst) (
    figure 6
    ):  These painless, large, cystic masses present during lactation and after weaning.  Diagnosis is made with breast ultrasonography and treatment is with aspiration/excision.

Lactational breast infections (eg, mastitis, abscess) are the most serious complications and are reviewed in a separate article.

Contraindications

Although breastfeeding is almost always recommended, there are contraindications (

) (which may be temporary), including:

  • HIV infection without antiretroviral therapy or with antiretroviral therapy and a detectable viral load (in resource-rich areas where formula is readily available)
  • Active, untreated tuberculosis
  • Active herpetic breast lesions
  • Active varicella infection
  • Current chemotherapy or radiation therapy
  • Active substance use disorder (mothers who are prescribed methadone or buprenorphine for opioid use disorder can breastfeed if their urine drug screen remains negative for other substances)
  • Infant galactosemia (galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency)
